awd_titl_txt: Discrimination and Achievement Disparities in Adolescence
awd_abstract_narration:
Of great concern to the scientific, educator, and policy communities is why members of racial and ethnic minorities exhibit consistently lower achievement than non-Hispanic white students. The racial/ethnic achievement gap is observed as early as age three, and it widens across childhood and adolescence. This achievement gap has long-term consequences for employment and earnings, incarceration and reliance on government assistance, and health outcomes. Understanding how aspects of students' daily experiences relate to achievement is important in reducing this gap. This study focuses on adolescents' day-to-day experiences of discrimination -based on race/ethnicity, social class, weight, and/or sexual orientation- that may contribute to achievement disparities. This research will not only contribute to understanding of the achievement gap but may also lead to the development of new and innovative policy interventions. 

This study will include mixed-methods data from 1,000 students over a 3-year period during the transition from middle to high school. Using survey, daily diary, and interview data, this study investigates: a) the extent to which adolescents are marginalized by peers, educators, or institutions due to their race/ethnicity, social class, weight, and/or sexual minority status, b) how discrimination by specific perpetrators or discrimination tied to race/ethnicity and other social identities is linked to achievement, internalizing symptoms, and risky behaviors, and c) whether positive interpersonal interactions within the school walls (e.g., student-teacher or peer relations, school climate) protect students from the negative effects of discrimination. Project findings will suggest not only critical points of intervention but also whether intervention and prevention efforts could be effectively targeted to certain student populations by identifying those at greatest and least risk, and how contextual factors may foster resilience.

por.por_cntn:
Racial/ethnic disparities in achievement come at a major cost to individuals and society, which is why studying such disparities has long been a major concern in both scientific and policy communities. Studies that attempt to shed light on how achievement disparities are proliferated or mitigated have significant potential to inform efforts to improve the well-being of the population. We argue that this important goal is supported by focusing on adolescents’ experiences of discrimination in school, as discrimination is a source of social psychological disruption to academic progress that weighs more heavily on students of color and schools serve as both a principal setting to observe the risks posed by discrimination and a potential venue to take action. The discrimination that young people face in American society because of the color of their skin and/or the language they speak, however, is tangled up with other devalued social identities possessed by youth, such as being poor, obese, or a sexual minority. Our study seeks to understand the implications of the intersection of race/ethnicity with other social identities, which will both tap into the complicated nature of marginalization of American youth and provide potential insights into why experiences and effects of discrimination can vary within race/ethnic groups.

The aims of this National Science Foundation grant were to investigate how various stigmatized group memberships intersected and influenced experiences of discrimination, determine the extent to which constellations of discrimination were linked to adolescents’ academic performance and well-being, and identify to what degree the school context protected or exacerbated the negative effects of discrimination on adolescents’ well-being. Using survey data from more than 1,000 adolescents, we found that a large proportion of adolescents reported experiences of discrimination at school, perpetrated most commonly by peers but also by educators, and the majority attribute the reasons for their mistreatment to both race/ethnicity and other identities. Experiences of intersectional discrimination are linked to poorer mental health and lower levels of engagement in school. We are currently finalizing a manuscript of these findings for peer-reviewed publication.

Daily diary also provide insights into the links between discrimination and well-being. Using data from a 14-day daily diary study of racial/ethnic minority youth, Results indicated that daily discrimination was associated with shorter sleep duration, but support from teachers protected adolescents from some of the negative effects of daily discrimination on sleep. Given that sleep has been identified as a critical factor in both adolescent mental health and school performance, such findings suggest one health-related pathway by which discrimination might impact these other areas of well-being. This study also highlights the important role that teachers can play in the lives of youth who experience discrimination. A manuscript detailing these findings is currently revised and resubmitted to a peer-reviewed journal. Additional analyses currently in progress examine other aspects of school demographics and interpersonal processes that may serve to buffer the detrimental impacts of discrimination on adolescent well-being.

This line of research has the potential to advance theory (adding discrimination to perspectives on the achievement gap), emphasize intersectionality when considering discrimination, integrate contextual social psychological approaches to perception and interpersonal relations, and advance practice/policy by identifying who is most at risk and how best to intervene.
